Southampton’s business ahead of the 2014/15 season was a classic example of what good scouting and a well thought out transfer policy can provide. Luke Shaw went for £27 million, replaced by Ryan Bertrand for a third of the price. The money made on Shaw, Lallana, Lovren, Chambers and Lambert was re-invested in Dusan Tadic (£9 mill), Graziano Pelle (£8 mill) and Sadio Mane (£10.5 mill). With still in excess of £25 mill net spend, they finished 7th in the league.

Admittedly for every success story there is a club that is getting it all wrong. The less said about Sunderland’s transfer business the better. Newcastle’s pursuit of replacing the departed talent of Cabaye and Ben Arfa led them to the £12 million purchase of Remy Cabella, and deciding not to learn their lesson, a year later spent the same amount on Florian Thauvin. Payet cost the same price, and from the same league, but the difference between him and those two players and their ability to adapt to this league could not be more marked.

Manchester City’s pursuit of a centre back partner for Vincent Kompany is a classic case in point. All notion of sense and logic has disappeared at the club as they again and again plunder millions on players who do not seem up to the task, while Spurs paid £11 million for Toby Alderweireld – a far more reasonable sum for a player they knew was capable of performing in the Premier League. City are not alone – Manchester United have already rather brilliantly proven how £250 million can be spent to almost no effect.

But it’s much harder for the very best clubs to improve. The result is that the quality of the top four is static, relative to the big leaps that can fairly easily be taken by the Premier League’s rest. The point is not that the gap is ever going to close, but that it is narrower than it has been for over a decade. For the league as a spectacle, that can only be a good thing.

Look at what Stoke City have achieved under Mark Hughes – the strides they have made in the last couple of years. Their front line is made up of 3 ex-wonderkids in Shaqiri (Bayern), Bojan (Barca) and Arnautović (Inter), who lost their way but are now flourishing under Hughes in a team playing fast, attractive football. They are part of this “New Middle Class” along with Palace, Southampton and others. The bourgeoisie are making inroads on the aristocracy.

This is the worst nightmare for the likes of Abramovich or any other billionaire corporate owner because if your money can’t guarantee you success anymore, then you might have to start relying on other things, such as high quality scouting, good youth training and stability. But the biggest, richest clubs are no good at that stuff, really, and they’ve never had to be since being rich. Like a lot of wealthy people, they mostly use price tags to define quality, not knowledge.

If you want the best, go and buy the best – and that’s really the only mantra they know. Chelsea did it just over a decade ago – buy Makelele, Carvalho, Robben, Drogba and win back to back titles. Simple. But what if that’s run its course? Maybe very big money has stopped working. Are these clubs going to change though? Or will we see huge bids tabled for Ighalo, Vardy and Mahrez this transfer window? Transfer bids which more likely than not lack the oversight as to whether the player suits the club and the club suits the player. Like when Liverpool paid £35milion for Andy Carroll, or £32.5 million for Benteke, despite a lack of wingers at the club and a reluctance to put the ball in the box.

You still need to get a lot of other things right, but it means that when a top club’s best players are injured or off-form, the poorer clubs’ best players are good enough to beat the richer club. That for me is the biggest change I have seen this season. Growing up, and looking back to around the turn of the millenium, it felt like the only time Manchester United or Arsenal got beaten by one of the smaller teams in the league was through a backs to the wall, gritty performance – requiring a fair bit of luck and some resolute defending to secure the 3 points. This season, we are seeing mid table teams genuinely outplay the so called big guns – and it has happened to all of them. Stoke’s performances against both Man City and Man United, Bournemouth’s back to back wins over United and Chelsea, Watford’s 3-0 demolition of Liverpool, and Southampton’s 4-0 obliteration of Arsenal on Boxing Day. That’s before you even look at Leicester’s games or West Ham’s away wins at the Etihad, Anfield and the Emirates.

The environment is changing and the result is the Premier League is probably more competitive than it has been in a decade or so. There is a danger it could have a negative impact on European performance as constant attrition leads to weariness – which we have already seen in the Champions League this season – which in turn has lead to complaints about the quality of our best teams.

But quality is hard to define and, besides, which is preferable – a league in which one team lead 2nd by 19 points after 19 games, as in France with PSG, or one in which no one has a clue what is going to happen? With only 10 points separating 1st and 9th at the halfway point – I know which one I prefer.

The quest to conquer La Liga seems to hold a biblical aura similar to that of the Holy Grail for the rest of the league. You can count the number of clubs to win the Spanish top division since 1985 on one hand; Barcelona, Real Madrid, Atletico Madrid, Valencia and Deportivo. Competing with the financial might of The Galacticos of Real Madrid or Barcelona’s modern mix of tika-taka and talent development has proved close to impossible. Clubs have spent fortunes mounting a challenge on first or second place but none have managed to completely break the mould in La Liga.

The closest we have got was at the turn of the century, when Deportivo La Coruña and Valencia C.F were competing to become the league’s other team, genuinely big clubs. Deportivo did win the league in 2000. The previous year, Valencia had won the Copa del Rey. In a six-year spell from 98/99-03/04, between them they won three league titles, two Cups, three Spanish Super Cups and had two Pichichis (golden boot winners), plus two runners-up places, two Champions League final appearances and a semi-final, and a Uefa Cup. Deportivo took the Cup off Real’s galácticos on their 100th birthday and in their own stadium; Valencia took the league off them. Twice. Depor and Valencia were the alternative. Real contenders. For a while at least.

Deportivo La Coruña

There has been a lot of press coverage recently about the sad decline of Parma AC, who were amongst the standard bearers for brilliant Serie A football at the turn of the millennium. It’s arguable that in the modern age of superclubs, there are no sides like Parma out there anymore. Yes, with the winning combination of shrewd coaching and canny player recruitment, a team like Atletico Madrid, Porto or Borussia Dortmund can come to the fore and challenge the elite, albeit increasingly the field of honours seems to be monopolised by Europe’s behemoths. But before all the oil and TV money, continental sides had a chance to really develop with a core group of players who stuck in it for the long haul and challenged, however fleetingly, for the top honours. Deportivo fit the bill perfectly here, a team put together from tiny acorns from the unfashionable north west of Spain, giving the traditional powerhouses a bloody nose, even for a short time.

They won at the Camp Nou, the Bernabéu, San Siro, Delle Alpi, Highbury, the Parc de Princes, Munich’s Olympic Stadium and Old Trafford. They were 3-0 down to PSG, but beat them 4-3. They came from nowhere but reached a Champions League semi-final. They won the most hyped game ever, clinching the cup by beating Real Madrid at Real Madrid’s home on Real Madrid’s 100th birthday. They won a league title. They were big. For a while, they were amongst the biggest. They weren’t called Super Depor for nothing.

Depor had finished 2nd in La Liga in 1994 and 1995, winning the Copa Del Rey in the latter, the club storming into the limelight thanks to the brilliance of two young Brazilians. Signed for a combined €3million, Mauro Silva added class and power to midfield and goalscoring hero Bebeto, who would win the Pichichi in 1993 with 29 league goals. Mauro Silva went on to play 369 times for Depor across 13 years, and Bebeto scored 86 goals in 131 games in 4 seasons at the club. Together they laid the foundations for the club’s impending success.

When Bebeto left in 1996, Rivaldo arrived. He scored 21 league goals, as the club finished 3rd. When Barcelona activated Rivaldo’s €26 milion buyout clause within minutes before the end of the summer transfer window in 1997, it felt like a major backward step for the club. They would finish 12th that season.

The arrival of manager Javier Irureta from local rivals Celta Vigo in 1999 would change everything. They had a core, stable side with few glittering stars, including Naybet, Fran, Djalminha, Mauro Silva and Donato. Ahead of the 99/00 season, they made minimal changes – bringing in Victor, a Real Madrid reject, and Roy Makaay, a young, cheap and relatively unproductive striker from Tenerife. They would go on to win the league by 5 points. A Barcelona side that included Depor old boy Rivaldo, Patrick Kluivert, Luis Enrique, Luis Figo and the de Boer brothers could only finish 2nd. A glittering Real Madrid side with Iker Casillas, Fernando Hierro, Roberto Carlos, Fernando Redondo and Raul came 5th, despite winning the Champions League that same season. Depor hammered them 5-2 at the Riazor.

Depor were built on a strong spine. Towering centre backs in Naybet and Donato, and the Brazilian muscle in holding midfield of Mauro Silva and Flavio Conceicao. Fran and Victor provided the width, Roy Makaay with the goals (22 in 36 league games). And then there was Djalminha. Signed from Palmeiras after being named the best midfielder in Brazil in 1997, Djalminha’s 10 goals from 30 appearances were a major part in securing the title. He also gave one of the most memorable moments of the campaign with this outrageous piece of skill against Real Madrid. He was incredibly talented and always flamboyant – as keen to impress as Ronaldinho after him. This short highlight reel of him shows that perfectly.

Less than two years later, Djalminha had fallen out with Deportivo’s staff, players and fans. Like so many of football’s geniuses, the Brazilian’s talent was only matched by his bellicose behaviour. He was banished to Austria Vienna after headbutting Irureta on the training ground in 2002, his Depor career all but over. The tale does however have a happy ending; he rejoined Depor in 2008 as part of their indoor football side with keeper Jacques Songo’o, Fran, Naybet, and Donato. Not the kind of side you want to face hungover on a Sunday morning one imagines.

Success continued for Depor. They managed to finish 2nd in La Liga in consecutive proceeding seasons, won the Copa Del Rey in ’02 and the Spanish Super Cup in ’01 and ’03. They had two wonderful strikers in Tristan and Makaay. Tristan won the Pichichi in ’02 with 21 league goals, and Makaay went one better the following year, winning the European Golden Shoe with 29 league goals. Together they scored over 200 goals for the club. Makaay would move to Bayern Munich in 2003, scoring over 100 goals for the German club across 4 seasons. This hattrick against them might have had something to do with the €19 million that they paid for him.

Depor were not finished there. After making the last 8 in the Champions League in ’01 and ’02, they would go one better in 2004. Juan Carlos Valerón replaced Djalminha in the free role and the club went on one hell of a European journey. They faced Juventus, the previous years runners-up, in the round of 16, winning both games 1-0 before facing reigning champions AC Milan in the Quarter Final. After losing 4-1 at the San Siro, Depor performed miracles at the Riazor, turning the tie on its head to progress with a 4-0 win. If Istanbul is the biggest shock Milan have ever experienced, then this is a close second. Depor fell to eventual winners Porto in the Semi-Final, losing 1-0 on aggregate after a late Derlei penalty in the second leg at the Riazor.

It was donwfall from there on out for the club. Irureta moved on and out of the exit door followed half the first team. For the other half, including Fran, Donato, and Mauro Silva, retirement loomed. They were relegated in 2011 and again in 2013, but are back at the top table once again, finishing 16th this season. Everyone’s 2nd team in Spain, for a time they captured the imagination of so many both domestically and across Europe.

Valencia

Valencia can never be considered as one-time minnows relative to Deportivo. From the early 90s they had star-studded names both on the touchline and on the pitch. Guus Hiddink replaced Alfredo Di Stefano as manager in 1991, who in turn was replaced by Carlos Alberto Parreira, fresh from winning the 1994 World Cup with Brazil. They had great players – Andoni Zubizarreta, Oleg Salenko, Predrag Mijatovic, Romario, Ariel Ortega and Adrian Ilie.

Despite that, a 2nd place finish aside in 95-96, Valencia rarely threatened success until Hector Cuper arrived in 1999. They won the Copa Del Rey that season, followed by the Spanish Super Cup a year later. He took them to back to back Champions League finals, where they would lose both, firstly to a rampant Real Madrid and then in a tight final to Bayern that would be decided on penalties. Despite the lack of a trophy to show for it they enjoyed two fabulous runs to the final, including this 5-2 win over Lazio in the Quarter Final in 2000, and this 3-0 Semi Final win over Leeds the following year. Perhaps their finest hour was a 4-1 dismantling of Barcelona in the Semi Final in 2000 to take them to their first Champions League final.

You would be forgiven for thinking that was it for Valencia’s fleeting and unfulfilled attempt to succeed. After the first final, Claudio Lopez went to Lazio for €35 million to form an anticipated dream partnership with compatriot Hernan Crespo. Lopez had scored 47 goals in his last two seasons at Valencia including this cracker against PSG in 1999. When they lost to Bayern, Gaizka Mendieta followed Lopez to Lazio for a staggering €48 million.

Fans loved the tireless and tough Mendieta, one minute back in defence helping out, moments later up the other end feeding another ball into the channel for Lopez to seize on, and every now and again getting into the box himself. The sort of player everyone wanted in their team. It didn’t work out for him in Italy and despite an enjoyable spell on Teeside he never hit the heights of his time at the Mestalla, but there is no doubting that he was one of the world’s best midfielders at the turn of the millenium.

Despite the sale of key players, they were canny in the transfer market. Pablo Aimar joined from River Plate, Ruben Baraja from Atletico Madrid, Roberto Ayala from AC Milan and Vicente from Levante. They would form the backbone of the club’s most successful era, just in time for Rafa Benitez’s arrival in the summer of 2001.

The 2001/02 Valencia title winning side was, frankly, as boring a side as won a domestic league title in the whole decade. A return of just 51 goals scored in 38 games is a laughable total for a Championship-winning team (no other top 5 team scored less than 64) – but Valencia were incredibly well-organised, and masters of the 1-0 win. The key was the fact that Valencia effectively played three central midfielders at a time when the rest of Spain was only fielding two. They rarely lost possession, and when they did, they were quick to get nine men behind the ball. Goals were in short supply from around the team, but Mista (a player Benitez had brought through the Real Madrid youth team) had an excellent season, and always deserved more recognition than he received. Ruben Baraja and David Albelda were arguably the best midfield partnership of the decade – both intelligent passers and both positionally excellent in front of the back four.

The side changed very little in terms of personnel for their second league title in 2003/04, a season when they also won the UEFA Cup. They did, however, demonstrate that the 4-2-3-1 was not merely a defensive shape, and credit must go to Benitez for the attacking shift- they conceded the same number of goals as they did in 01/02 (27) but managed to score twenty more goals, only one fewer than the league’s top scorers, Real Madrid. Mista became even better and Vicente added the goalscoring ability that was so clearly lacking when he first joined the club, and Valencia were without question the best side in Spain. Their run to the UEFA Cup final was less spectacular, and they won a poor final 2-0 against Marseille, effectively decided by one incident in the first half (Fabien Barthez bringing down Mista, being sent-off, and Vicente converting the resulting penalty). Mista added a second and that was that – both for the game and for Benitez’s time as manager. A new challenge on Merseyside beckoned. From 1999 up until the end of the 2004 season, Valencia had won a total of two La Liga titles, one UEFA Cup, one Copa del Rey, and one UEFA Super Cup in those six years, no less than five first class titles and two Champions League finals had been achieved.

Valencia’s post Benitez era has been overrun by debt as the club have attempted to build and move into the 75,000 seater Nou Mestalla during a time of Spain’s deep and long running recession. It has meant selling their best players – David Villa, David Silva, Juan Mata, Roberto Soldado, Jordi Alba and more. Despite that they have over-achieved – they have never since threatened to take the title but they did finish 3rd three years in a row between 2010 and 2012. After a 4th placed finish last season, they are now owned by Singapore businessman Peter Lim, and perhaps another onslaught on the big two looms.
